Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 02:42PM fortunate1 wrote: Mirbelle, I was scared and very ignorant. If you end up with Dr. Wallace or Dr. Blair, They work with PS Dr. James Chao, but I don't imagine it's an exclusive thing. My friend hasn't been reconstructed yet, but I understand he's very very good. Who did your husband go to? Curious. Dr. Barone is new, but is being noticed right away, I guess.
Posts.Title: Good Mx surgeon in San Diego? mlrbelle unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 02:06PM - edited Oct 8, 2009 02:22PM by fortunate1 Dr Sarah Blair, also at UCSD/Moores Cancer Center. A friend had her as her surgeon. I have heard enthusiastic recommendations from three docs (including my BS and PS) for Dr. Julie Barone at Sharp. How wonderful to be checking ahead of time, I was in such a panicked rush.
Posts.Title: Good Mx surgeon in San Diego? mlrbelle unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 01:02PM fortunate1 wrote: Hi BRCA1. Wow, this is quite a distraction while you wait for surgery. I am so sorry you two have this worry. I think Leaf has good answers for you. Write down every question you can think of for the Dr. appt. and make sure you understand the answers. My BC was lobular, which doesn't usually show up as a lump and isn't round. It also is easy to miss on a mammo. Mine conveniently did form a lump for me to find, which was confirmed with ultrasound. I pushed on it a lot while working my way through a prolonged diagnostic period, so it did indeed feel bruised. Don't know if this helps at all.  I hope that the Doc can give her some peace of mind (and maybe a biopsy).
Posts.Title: MRI showed 1.8cm ...plus pain???HELP BRCA1 fortunate1

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 09:01AM fortunate1 wrote: Hi BRCA1, My lump stayed a little sore, but was definite with any pressure. It was in very shallow tissue and had no way to escape my concerned poking. Are you and your sister writing that list? Remember that most suspicious findings turn out to be benign, and her youth is in her favor. The BRCA status is a worry, as you know all too well. I would want a clear plan of watchfulness by the doctors after they hopefully find nothing wrong.
Posts.Title: MRI showed 1.8cm ...plus pain???HELP BRCA1 fortunate1

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 12:18PM fortunate1 wrote: I had a 20.5 score. My Onc said the benefit from chemo wasn't enough to recommend it. His convincing explanation.... if 100 women in your exact situation took chemo, only three would benefit. Femara is where the benefit lies for me. These are scary decisions to make. Especially when your Onc isn't in agreement. You must be one strong woman!
Posts.Title: Anyone with an intermediate oncotype? Lovelillian nem126

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 11:33AM fortunate1 wrote: I found the lump myself. A mammogram 9 months before, and one after I felt the lump, showed nothing. My breasts are dense and lumpy, so I had always figured that mammograms would have to determine what was what. Definitely not so. It felt like a bean, quite firm and slightly movable, a lucky thing with lobular BC. There is no BC history in my family.

Posts.Title: How I waited for surgery... JGrim kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 06:22PM fortunate1 wrote: Just to be different, 61. Found the lump myself, lobular, never showed on any mammogram, so who knows how long it was there. I guess I can actually be thankful for a lump. I tell any woman who will listen to do her self exams.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 07:01PM fortunate1 wrote: I am in Calif. on the other side of the continent from you, so I can't recommend a PS. But I wanted to rcommend the surgery. It is much easier on the body. I had one, one side only, and was feeling fine very quickly. 2 day stay in the hospital and no tissue expander/exchange process. I was not a candidate for nipple sparing. The cosmetic result is beautiful. The PS and I have some details to work out, but my only issues with my new breast are really just me getting used to the change.
Posts.Title: Nipple Sparing Alloderm w/Implant Breast Reconstruction brynze clemmons64

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 07:17PM fortunate1 wrote: Hi, another stage 1 here. I sympathize with the fear of mammograms. I am on the sloooow crawl through my one year anniversaries of bad stuff. Three months of fear between the lump and the surgery. The one year mammo is coming up in a few weeks. Here's hoping like crazy for smooth sailing and no fear. After all, I am fortunate in this BC world, as are we all. We found it early. Is it OK to say that? or even think that?
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 02:02PM fortunate1 wrote: With the middle range oncotype score you will find all kinds of different decisions for all kinds of reasons. I assumed with a 20.5 oncotype I would have chemo. It was my onc who said the benefit wasn't enough to do it. I was scared and it took a bit of convincing, but I did not do chemo. Femara is what my onc said would be of the most benefit. Good luck with a hard decision.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 08:35PM fortunate1 wrote: Don't be a patient patient. My oncologist's assistant didn't send my sample. Genomic Health was great, but they hadn't received it, and the assistant never returned my phone calls. It took my DH going to the onc's office and waiting for an answer before things were finally underway. So keep calling until you're sure the sample is really on it's way.

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 04:00PM fortunate1 wrote: Wow, these comments are really amazing. I must have pretty considerate friends. The worst I got was "did they get it all?". I probably would have said it myself before I got BC, not realizing it's what we fear so much and will think about forever........did they get it all? Oh yeah, there was one other comment, about me having "cancer lite". Relatively true, yes, but heavy enough to change my life and my body. I've got to get one of those t shirts.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 06:27PM fortunate1 wrote: I have RA, am taking Methotrexate and Plaquenil, and it's very well under control. I'm also a bit too close to Osteoporosis and being treated with Reclast and vitamin D. Now I've started Femara and am hoping it doesn't throw me back into RA symptoms or weaken my bones further. No SE yet except for night sweats. Neither rheumatologist or oncologist were sure what any interactions would be. A pharmacist said it would be fine. Hope so.  Anyone in the same situation?
Posts.Title: How many with BC and autoimmune diseases like LUPUS, RA, ? badboob67 wintersocks

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 07:29PM fortunate1 wrote: I got the oncotype test after a unhappy little battle of miscommunications. It came back with a score of 20.5 which is in the low intermediate category. My ONC said definitely no chemo, which surprised me but I trust him. I have to figure the MX got everything, no nodes is wonderful and Femara is my insurance policy. I worry anyway. I think we all excel at it.

Turns out we can relax a bit, though its almost impossible to do.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2010 05:12PM fortunate1 wrote: I was pretty similar to your stats. The gray area is an awful place to be. My Onc and DH(statistics guy) explained the statistics to me and I eventually agreed..... no chemo. The 3% improvement? They said it this way - that if 100 BC patients with my stats opted for chemo, only 3 of them would have any benefit. That did it for me. The Onc said that Femara was the big fighter for me. I still dither about it all now and then, but I trust the Onc.  Good luck
